lens.lens_summary: Becker's framework reveals that hosting on Split Lease forces a confrontation with the terror that one's private domestic space — the innermost layer of character armor — must be exposed, priced, judged, and physically occupied by a stranger, turning everyday repression-maintenance (the 'vital lie' that one controls one's own territory and destiny) into an active, phase-by-phase negotiation with existential vulnerability.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Discovery is the moment the host's existing hero system — their way of managing income, housing costs, and self-worth — is destabilized by the possibility of a new arrangement. Becker argues that 'man cuts out for himself a manageable world: he throws himself into action uncritically, unthinkingly' (Ch. 2). The host has been living inside the vital lie that their current financial and domestic arrangement is adequate. Hearing about Split Lease cracks that lie open just enough to create what Zilboorg calls the 'sense of insecurity in the face of danger.' The user stories show that 'value before the ask — always' is critical because hosts at discovery are not yet willing to trade information for an uncertain promise; they need to see the system working before they risk lowering their defenses. The host's character armor is intact here; they are browsing from behind it, testing whether this new hero system (platform-mediated hosting) might be safer than the current one.

user_state.emotional_state: Guarded curiosity mixed with latent financial anxiety; the host's character armor is fully engaged, scanning for threats before allowing any openness
user_state.knowledge_level: Minimal — the host knows the concept exists but has not internalized its mechanics; perception is filtered through existing hero systems (Craigslist, Airbnb, word-of-mouth)
user_state.commitment_level: Near-zero; the host is in what Becker calls the 'peasant equanimity' of pre-awareness, not yet startled into action
user_state.data_available: Referral source, landing page views, time-on-page — all behavioral signals of approach-avoidance

reasons: The vital lie of the current arrangement ('I'm fine as I am') has not yet been sufficiently challenged
No inner sustainment from the platform yet — the host has no delegated power to lean on
Becker's Jonah Syndrome: the host may fear their own capacity to succeed at hosting, and the exposure that comes with it
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories file: 'Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first.' This maps directly to Becker's point that character defenses are only lowered when the organism encounters 'a working amount of basic narcissism' — the platform must provide narcissistic supply (value, validation) before the host will lower defenses.

key_quotes.quote: He accepts the cultural programming that turns his nose where he is supposed to look; he doesn't bite the world off in one piece as a giant would, but in small manageable pieces, as a beaver does.
key_quotes.relevance: The host at discovery is a beaver encountering a new world — they need the platform to present itself in small, manageable, non-threatening pieces, not as a giant existential proposition.

key_quotes.quote: Value before the ask — always. Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them.
key_quotes.relevance: Asking for personal information before demonstrating value is, in Beckerian terms, asking someone to lower their character armor before providing a replacement defense structure.

evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: Evaluation is where the host's repression system goes to work comparing hero systems. Becker writes that we 'always rely on something that transcends us, some system of ideas and powers in which we are embedded and which support us' (Ch. 4). The host is now comparing Split Lease to Craigslist, Airbnb, and roommate apps — not just on features, but on which system offers the most robust character defense. The user stories emphasize that 'verified reviews and host credibility signals activate guests,' but the inverse is equally true: the host needs to see that the platform has a credibility infrastructure that will protect them. This is the host seeking what Becker calls 'delegated powers' — embedding themselves in a system strong enough to banish the fear of inviting strangers. The 'guaranteed income' promise in the journey-types.json is a direct death-anxiety buffer: it converts the terrifying uncertainty of stranger-dependence into predictable, controlled income.

user_state.emotional_state: Active comparison anxiety — the host is weighing which hero system to trust with their most intimate asset; fear of making the wrong choice is a displaced death anxiety
user_state.knowledge_level: Growing but fragmented — the host has read about guarantees, fees, and process but has not yet internalized enough to feel 'inner sustainment'
user_state.commitment_level: Low-to-moderate; the host is in what Becker calls the 'flirtation with anxiety' — drawn toward the new system but simultaneously repelled by its demands
user_state.data_available: Pages visited (pricing page, FAQ, competitor comparison), time spent on trust signals (reviews, guarantees), return visits

reasons: If the platform fails to present itself as a superior hero system to alternatives, the host retreats to their existing vital lie
Lack of social proof functions as a failure of 'inner sustainment' — the host cannot borrow confidence from others' success
The host may encounter the Jonah Syndrome: evaluating the full scope of what hosting demands and shrinking back from their own potential
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Verified reviews and host credibility signals activate guests... Every review is a past guest activating a future one. The trust infrastructure is cross-activation infrastructure.' For the host evaluating the platform, this same trust infrastructure is what Becker would call the 'imagined infallibility of the world around him' — without it, the host cannot embed in the system.

key_quotes.quote: We don't want to admit that we do not stand alone, that we always rely on something that transcends us, some system of ideas and powers in which we are embedded and which support us.
key_quotes.relevance: Evaluation is the host auditioning Split Lease as a new transcendent system to embed in. The platform must feel larger and more reliable than the host's individual capacity.

key_quotes.quote: A skeptical guest who sees verified reviews, ID checks, and real host history doesn't need the platform to convince them — another user already did.
key_quotes.relevance: Cross-activation is Becker's delegated power in marketplace form: one person's successful experience becomes the character armor another borrows during evaluation.

onboarding.what_this_lens_reveals: Onboarding is the first moment the host voluntarily lowers their character armor. They provide identity verification, personal details, and connect with an assigned agent. In Becker's framework, this is a controlled 'death and rebirth' — the host sheds some of their autonomous self-sufficiency and is 'reborn' as a platform participant with delegated powers. The agent relationship (e.g., Bryant from the journey types) is critical because it provides what Saul calls 'inner sustainment' — a human anchor that compensates for the vulnerability of self-exposure. The user stories note that 'authentication should be invisible until it matters,' which maps to Becker's insight that repression must be gentle and gradual — forcing the host to confront too much reality too quickly (full-page redirects, invasive forms) will trigger defensive retreat. The host is allowing the platform to become what Becker calls a 'protective superego.'

user_state.emotional_state: Cautious surrender — the host is trading autonomy for the promise of a stronger defensive structure; there is relief mixed with vulnerability
user_state.knowledge_level: Moderate — the host now understands the basic mechanics but has not yet tested them with real stakes
user_state.commitment_level: Moderate — identity verification and agent assignment create psychological sunk costs that function as new character armor
user_state.data_available: Profile completion rate, verification status, first agent call completion, time between signup and first listing action

reasons: If onboarding feels invasive rather than supportive, it triggers what Becker calls 'the fear of losing support, of standing alone' — the host feels exposed without adequate replacement defenses
The agent relationship is a single point of failure: if the agent is unresponsive or impersonal, the host loses their primary source of delegated power
Identity verification forces confrontation with one's real, unarmored self — a miniature version of Perls' impasse layer
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Authentication should be invisible until it matters. Inline auth pop-up, not a full-page redirect. Users don't lose search context.' Journey map: 'The Host clicks to sign in and is presented with a modal.' Both sources confirm that the transition from anonymous browsing to identified participant must be as frictionless as possible — in Beckerian terms, the character armor must be peeled, not ripped.

key_quotes.quote: The great scientific simplification of psychoanalysis is the concept that the whole of early experience is an attempt by the child to deny the anxiety of his emergence, his fear of losing his support, of standing alone, helpless and afraid.
key_quotes.relevance: Onboarding recapitulates this childhood dynamic: the host is 'emerging' into a new system and needs to feel supported, not abandoned, at every step.

key_quotes.quote: Authentication should be invisible until it matters. Inline auth pop-up, not a full-page redirect. Users don't lose search context.
key_quotes.relevance: Preserving context during authentication is preserving the host's character armor during a vulnerable transition — the platform must not break the spell of safety.

listing_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: CRITICAL PHASE. Listing creation is where the host performs what Becker would recognize as the most terrifying act in the entire journey: voluntarily exposing the innermost layer of their character armor — their private domestic space — to public scrutiny. The home is not merely a physical asset; it is the primary hero system, the material expression of the vital lie that one has built a manageable, controlled world. Every photo uploaded, every amenity checked, every house rule written is an act of translation from the private symbolic order (where the space means safety, identity, control) into the public transactional order (where it means square footage, nightly rate, and guest reviews). Becker's Perls-derived four layers of neurotic defense are directly operative here: the cliche layer is the listing template ('Load Common features'), the role-playing layer is the host performing the role of 'landlord' through the wizard, the impasse layer is the moment the host confronts what is truly at stake (a stranger will sleep in my home), and the death layer is the terror that this exposure could result in judgment, damage, or loss of the space that anchors their identity. The user stories confirm this: 'Completion percentage is a good host nudge. Hosts need to know what's unfinished before a listing goes live.' This nudge works precisely because it converts the overwhelming existential act of self-exposure into small, manageable checkboxes — Becker's beaver biting off manageable pieces. The six-step wizard structure itself is a character defense: it represses the totality of what the host is doing by fragmenting it into discrete, non-threatening steps.

user_state.emotional_state: Deep ambivalence — creative pride in one's space wars with terror of exposure; the host oscillates between the Jonah Syndrome (fear of their own potential as a successful host) and defensive minimization (underrepresenting the space to maintain control)
user_state.knowledge_level: Functional — the host understands the mechanics of listing creation but not the psychological weight of what they are doing
user_state.commitment_level: Moderate-to-high — each completed wizard step is a small death of privacy and a small birth of the host identity, creating momentum that is hard to reverse
user_state.data_available: Wizard step completion rates, time per step, photo count and quality, drop-off point in wizard, use of 'Load Common' vs. manual entry, number of house rules written

reasons: Photo upload is the existential crux: converting private space into public image forces the host through the impasse layer where they feel 'empty and lost' (Perls via Becker)

The house rules step is where the host's need for control (character armor) collides with the reality that rules are only necessary because strangers will be present — the rules are an admission of vulnerability

The Jonah Syndrome peaks here: the host glimpses what successful hosting would mean (strangers in their space, income dependence, public identity) and 'shivers with weakness, awe and fear before these very same possibilities' (Maslow via Becker)
Incomplete listings that never go live are the Beckerian equivalent of the organism shrinking back from full exposure to preserve the vital lie
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Completion percentage is a good host nudge... A visible progress indicator on the listing card creates just enough friction to get them to finish — without being in the way.' Also: 'Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it. Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.' The pause function is a Beckerian masterstroke: it allows the host to retreat from exposure without destroying the character work already invested — it preserves the new hero system in suspended animation rather than forcing a binary death.

key_quotes.quote: The defenses that form a person's character support a grand illusion, and when we grasp this we can understand the full drivenness of man. He is driven away from himself, from self-knowledge, self-reflection. He is driven toward things that support the lie of his character.
key_quotes.relevance: The listing wizard must support the host's grand illusion that they are merely filling out a form, not performing an act of existential self-exposure. Every UX decision that makes this feel routine rather than momentous serves the vital lie.

key_quotes.quote: The third layer is a stiff one to penetrate: it is the 'impasse' that covers our feeling of being empty and lost... Underneath this layer is the fourth and most baffling one: the 'death' or fear-of-death layer.
key_quotes.relevance: Photo upload and rules-setting force the host through the impasse layer. The wizard must not let the host linger here — it must move them quickly to the submission confirmation, which functions as a rebirth moment.

key_quotes.quote: Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it. Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.
key_quotes.relevance: Pause is character armor for the listing itself — it allows the host to maintain the vital lie that they are 'still deciding' rather than confronting the finality of either full exposure or full retreat.

key_quotes.quote: A 'Title and Description Suggestions' modal may appear, which the Host dismisses.
key_quotes.relevance: Even AI-generated suggestions can feel threatening at this phase: the host wants to control the narrative of their own space. The dismissal is a reassertion of character armor against the platform's attempt to mediate self-presentation.

pricing.what_this_lens_reveals: CRITICAL PHASE. Pricing forces the host to assign a monetary value to something that is psychologically priceless — their home, their sanctuary, the physical manifestation of their hero system. Becker writes that 'man could strut and boast all he wanted, but that he really drew his courage to be from... the fetish of money and the size of a bank balance' (Ch. 4). The pricing step inverts this: instead of drawing self-esteem from money, the host must convert self-esteem into money. Setting the price too high is a defense mechanism (making the space unaffordable protects it from invasion), while setting it too low triggers what Becker calls the fear of self-deprecation — 'we tend to be afraid of any knowledge that could cause us to despise ourselves or to make us feel inferior, weak, worthless' (Maslow via Becker, Ch. 4). The journey map notes that 'default values already populated' in the pricing step, and the host 'reviews and accepts the defaults.' This default-acceptance pattern is profoundly Beckerian: it is the host delegating the most anxiety-laden decision to the platform's authority, using the platform as what Becker calls an 'other-power' to avoid the existential weight of self-valuation. The user stories' 'guaranteed income' concern is the host seeking what Becker calls an 'immunity bath' against the terror of financial unpredictability.

user_state.emotional_state: Acute vulnerability masked by pragmatism — the host treats pricing as a financial calculation to avoid confronting it as an existential one; accepting defaults is a relief mechanism
user_state.knowledge_level: Low-to-moderate on market dynamics; the host often lacks confidence in their own pricing judgment, which is why defaults are so readily accepted
user_state.commitment_level: High — pricing is the penultimate step before going live; the host has already invested significant character-work and retreating now would feel like a failure of the new hero system
user_state.data_available: Default acceptance rate vs. manual override rate, price sensitivity analysis, time spent on pricing step, correlation between pricing confidence and listing completion

reasons: If defaults feel too low, the host experiences self-deprecation anxiety — their space (and by extension their identity) is being undervalued by the system they trusted
If defaults feel too high, the host fears no one will come — the space will be publicly exposed and publicly rejected, the worst possible outcome for the vital lie
The fee structure (Split Lease's cut) can trigger betrayal anxiety: the platform that promised to be a protective superego is now extracting value from the host's vulnerability
Pricing makes the transactional nature of hosting undeniable, piercing through whatever romantic or communal framing the host has used to rationalize their participation
dropout_risk.evidence: Journey map: 'The pricing section appears with default values already populated. The Host reviews and accepts the defaults.' Journey-types.json: key concern is 'Pricing fairness and income predictability.' The combination reveals that the host needs the platform to pre-digest the anxiety of self-valuation — defaults function as the platform saying 'this is what you are worth,' absorbing the existential burden.

key_quotes.quote: Man could strut and boast all he wanted, but he really drew his 'courage to be' from a god, a string of sexual conquests, a Big Brother, a flag, the proletariat, and the fetish of money and the size of a bank balance.
key_quotes.relevance: Pricing reverses this flow: instead of drawing courage from money, the host must convert their courage (the decision to host) into a monetary figure, exposing the transactional underbelly of the vital lie.

key_quotes.quote: We tend to be afraid of any knowledge that could cause us to despise ourselves or to make us feel inferior, weak, worthless, evil, shameful.
key_quotes.relevance: An underpriced listing is a direct assault on self-esteem; an overpriced listing that attracts no guests is a public confirmation of worthlessness. The pricing step is a self-esteem minefield.

key_quotes.quote: The pricing section appears with default values already populated. The Host reviews and accepts the defaults, clicking 'Next' to continue.
key_quotes.relevance: Default acceptance is the host delegating the terror of self-valuation to the platform — an act of embedding in other-power that Becker identifies as the fundamental human strategy for managing death anxiety.

proposal_mgmt.what_this_lens_reveals: CRITICAL PHASE. Proposal management is the moment the host must decide whether to allow a specific, named stranger into the physical space that constitutes their primary hero system. This is Becker's terror of death made interpersonal: the stranger represents the uncontrollable, the contingent, the intrusion of chaotic reality into the carefully managed world. Becker writes about 'the nightmarish, demonic frenzy in which nature has unleashed billions of individual organismic appetites' (Ch. 4) — accepting a proposal means voluntarily inviting one of those appetites into the sanctuary. The user stories reveal that 'the proposal itself is a cross-activation event' and that 'a well-structured proposal activates the host to respond.' In Beckerian terms, a well-structured proposal provides enough information to allow the host's character defenses to process the stranger as manageable rather than terrifying. The counter-offer mechanism (host changes duration from 16 to 10 weeks in the journey map) is a pure expression of character armor: the host is asserting control over the terms of their own vulnerability, reducing the duration of exposure to contain the existential risk. The 'Yes, Proceed' confirmation dialog functions as what Becker calls the moment when 'the Angel of Death extends his wing' — it forces a microsecond of genuine awareness before repression re-engages.

user_state.emotional_state: Heightened vigilance — the host is performing a life-safety assessment disguised as a business negotiation; every detail of the proposal is scanned for threat signals
user_state.knowledge_level: Functional but emotionally distorted — the host knows how proposals work but filters every data point through anxiety about stranger-intrusion
user_state.commitment_level: Variable and conditional — commitment fluctuates with each proposal detail; a single threatening signal can collapse it entirely
user_state.data_available: Proposal view-to-response time, counter-offer rate, counter-offer patterns (what gets changed most), acceptance vs. decline ratio, time between notification and first action

reasons: Each proposal is a confrontation with the reality that the host has made themselves available to strangers — the vital lie ('I'm just exploring') can no longer hold
Insufficient guest information triggers what Becker calls being 'forsaken by the protecting superego' — the platform has failed to vet the stranger adequately
The counter-offer mechanism, while empowering, also extends the anxiety window — each round of negotiation is another cycle of approach-avoidance
An experienced guest applying to a new host (per user stories) reduces anxiety through delegated credibility, but a new guest with no history provides no such buffer
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'An experienced guest applying to a new host is cross-activation in action. Their history, their reviews, their familiarity with how things work — it all reduces the host's anxiety.' Also: 'A well-structured proposal — clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent — activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction.' Journey map: 'The Host changes the duration from 16 weeks to 10 weeks using the duration dropdown.' The duration reduction is the host asserting temporal control — shortening the period of vulnerability to a psychologically bearable length.

key_quotes.quote: Each thing, in order to deliciously expand, is forever gobbling up others. Appetites may be innocent because they are naturally given, but any organism caught in the myriad cross-purposes of this planet is a potential victim of this very innocence.
key_quotes.relevance: The guest's innocent need for housing is, from the host's unconscious perspective, an appetite that threatens to gobble up their sanctuary. Proposal management is the negotiation of how much gobbling to permit.

key_quotes.quote: When someone who's already used Split Lease applies to a host who's never had a guest, that guest's reputation does the selling. Their history, their reviews, their familiarity with how things work — it all reduces the host's anxiety.
key_quotes.relevance: An experienced guest's track record functions as what Becker calls 'delegated powers' — the host borrows the confidence of past hosts who survived the encounter, using their reviews as character armor.

key_quotes.quote: The Host changes the duration from 16 weeks to 10 weeks using the duration dropdown. They click 'Update Proposal.'
key_quotes.relevance: Shortening the duration is the host's character defense in action: reducing the time horizon of vulnerability to a span the ego can manage without panic.

key_quotes.quote: The fear of death is to be regarded as an analogue of the fear of castration, and the situation to which the ego reacts is the state of being forsaken or deserted by the protecting superego — by the powers of destiny.
key_quotes.relevance: If the platform fails to provide adequate guest vetting, the host feels forsaken by the platform-as-superego, and the terror of inviting an unknown stranger becomes unmanageable.

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: The active lease phase is where the host's vital lie undergoes its most sustained test. The stranger is now physically present in the hero system. Becker writes that character armor is 'a necessary and basic dishonesty about oneself and one's whole situation' (Ch. 4), and during active lease the host must maintain this dishonesty while a stranger literally inhabits the physical structure that supports it. The journey map describes a rich set of control mechanisms — the Date Change Tool, cleaning photos, arrival notifications, the House Manual — and each of these is, in Beckerian terms, a character defense externalized into platform infrastructure. The House Manual is particularly significant: it is the host's attempt to impose their symbolic order on the guest's behavior, to make the stranger conform to the rules of the hero system rather than disrupting them. The stay review system functions as what Becker calls the 'instinct of self-preservation' made social: each review is the host monitoring whether the guest's presence has damaged or preserved the sanctuary. Cleaning photos sent by the guest are the most Beckerian feature in the entire platform: they are proof that the space has survived contact with the stranger's 'organismic appetites' and been restored to its pre-invasion state — a ritual purification that allows repression to re-engage.

user_state.emotional_state: Chronic low-grade vigilance punctuated by relief cycles — each successful stay completion temporarily restores the vital lie, each new arrival re-triggers anxiety
user_state.knowledge_level: High and growing — the host now has direct experiential knowledge that either reinforces or undermines their character defenses
user_state.commitment_level: High but fragile — the host is locked into a lease but psychologically the commitment must be renewed with each stay cycle
user_state.data_available: Stay completion rate, date change frequency and direction (adds vs. removes), cleaning photo submission rate, review scores given and received, messaging frequency and sentiment, payment regularity

reasons: A single negative stay experience can shatter the vital lie that hosting is manageable, triggering what Becker calls a 'psychotic break' in miniature — the host sees the raw reality of stranger-in-home without the buffering of character defenses
The accumulation of small violations (late arrivals, imperfect cleaning, minor rule-breaking) erodes character armor through attrition rather than rupture
If the payment system fails or is delayed, the host loses the primary self-esteem buffer (guaranteed income) that justified the exposure
Date change requests from the guest feel like the stranger asserting control over the host's territory — a direct challenge to the hero system
dropout_risk.evidence: Journey map: 'Guest notifies arrival... Guest sends cleaning photos... Both parties review each stay.' These micro-rituals are designed to maintain the host's sense of control, but their very necessity reveals the underlying anxiety they manage. User stories: 'Urgency should surface first on the dashboard. Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings — that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.' The host's need for an urgency dashboard is the need for a control console — a Beckerian 'manageable world' reduced to a screen of actionable items.

key_quotes.quote: Such constant expenditure of psychological energy on the business of preserving life would be impossible if the fear of death were not as constant. The very term 'self-preservation' implies an effort against some force of disintegration.
key_quotes.relevance: The constant monitoring of stays — arrival notifications, cleaning photos, reviews — is the host's self-preservation instinct externalized into platform rituals. The effort is constant because the threat (stranger in home) is constant.

key_quotes.quote: He uses all kinds of techniques, which we call the 'character defenses': he learns not to expose himself, not to stand out; he learns to embed himself in other-power, both of concrete persons and of things and cultural commands.
key_quotes.relevance: The House Manual, house rules, and review system are 'cultural commands' the host creates to embed the guest in the host's power structure — transforming the stranger from an uncontrollable threat into a rule-following participant in the host's hero system.

key_quotes.quote: At the end of each stay, the Guest takes and sends photos showing the space has been cleaned and left in good condition. This serves as documentation for both parties.
key_quotes.relevance: Cleaning photos are a ritual proof of reversibility — evidence that the existential risk of stranger-intrusion has been survived and the sanctuary restored. This is Becker's repression made photographic.

retention.what_this_lens_reveals: Retention is where the host must decide whether to rebuild their vital lie around hosting (re-list, renew) or retreat to their pre-hosting character armor. Becker writes that 'the irony of man's condition is that the deepest need is to be free of the anxiety of death and annihilation; but it is life itself which awakens it, and so we must shrink from being fully alive' (Ch. 4). A host who has successfully completed a lease has been more 'fully alive' — more exposed, more vulnerable, more engaged with contingency — than they were before. Retention asks: can you sustain that level of aliveness? The user stories show that 'Pause matters more than delete' — and this is the retention question in Beckerian form. The host who pauses is maintaining the possibility of continued aliveness without committing to it. The host who deletes is performing what Becker calls a retreat to the 'peasant equanimity' of pre-awareness. The host who re-lists has successfully integrated hosting into a new, expanded vital lie — one that includes the managed presence of strangers as a component of the hero system rather than a threat to it.

user_state.emotional_state: Post-exposure processing — the host is either integrating the hosting experience into a new, expanded character structure or rejecting it to restore the old one
user_state.knowledge_level: High — the host now has experiential knowledge of the full cycle and can make informed decisions, though these decisions are still filtered through character defenses
user_state.commitment_level: Bifurcated — hosts who had positive experiences show high re-engagement; those who experienced character-armor breaches show sharp withdrawal
user_state.data_available: Re-listing rate, time between lease end and re-listing, referral behavior, listing modifications between cycles, pause vs. delete ratio

reasons: The vital lie of hosting is harder to maintain the second time because the host now knows what it actually entails — Becker's 'disappearance of the fear of death' through repression is harder to achieve with experiential memory
If the platform fails to provide adequate post-lease validation (income summary, positive reviews, success metrics), the host loses the narcissistic supply needed to sustain the new hero system
External life changes (relationship shifts, job changes) can destabilize the entire character structure that made hosting possible
The host may have used the first lease as a 'test' within their old vital lie ('I'll just try it once') and now faces the genuine decision of whether to restructure their identity around hosting
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it. Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.' The regret associated with deletion is Beckerian: it is the grief of destroying a hero system one built at existential cost. Pause preserves the option to re-engage without forcing the host to confront the finality of retreat.

key_quotes.quote: The irony of man's condition is that the deepest need is to be free of the anxiety of death and annihilation; but it is life itself which awakens it, and so we must shrink from being fully alive.
key_quotes.relevance: Retention is the test of whether the host can remain 'fully alive' as a host — exposed, vulnerable, engaged — or whether they must shrink back to the safety of not-hosting.

key_quotes.quote: The neurotic who has had therapy is like a member of Alcoholics Anonymous: he can never take his cure for granted, and the best sign of the genuineness of that cure is that he lives with humility.
key_quotes.relevance: The returning host is like the recovering neurotic: they can never take their comfort with hosting for granted. Each re-listing is a humble recommitment to living with the anxiety of exposure.

key_quotes.quote: Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it. Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing.
key_quotes.relevance: Pause is the Beckerian middle path between the terror of continued exposure and the grief of total retreat — it allows the host to maintain the vital lie that they are 'still a host' without bearing the active cost.

cross_phase_patterns.description: Character armor is not shed all at once but in a carefully sequenced cascade: discovery cracks the existing lie, evaluation shops for a replacement, onboarding transfers allegiance, listing creation exposes the innermost layer, pricing assigns value to the exposed self, proposal management tests that exposure against a real person, active lease sustains it, and retention asks if it can be rebuilt. Each phase removes one layer of defense while simultaneously providing a new, platform-mediated replacement. If any phase fails to provide the replacement defense before removing the existing one, the host drops out.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Becker Ch. 4: 'Perls conceived the neurotic structure as a thick edifice built up of four layers.' The eight-phase host journey maps onto and extends Perls' four layers: cliche (discovery/evaluation), role-playing (onboarding/listing creation), impasse (pricing/proposal management), death layer (active lease/retention).

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Delegated Power as the Core Platform Promise
cross_phase_patterns.description: At every phase, the host is seeking what Becker calls 'other-power' — the ability to embed in a system stronger than themselves. The platform's guarantees, defaults, agents, review systems, and control tools all function as delegated power. The host never truly stands alone; they transfer dependency from their old hero system (managing the home alone) to a new one (managing through the platform). The user stories' cross-activation framework is Becker's delegated power in marketplace form: each user's successful experience becomes armor another user borrows.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Becker Ch. 4: 'He learns to embed himself in other-power, both of concrete persons and of things and cultural commands.' User stories: 'When someone who's already used Split Lease applies to a host who's never had a guest, that guest's reputation does the selling.'

cross_phase_patterns.description: The ability to pause, delay, or partially retreat appears across multiple phases and consistently functions as a character defense that prevents total collapse. Incomplete listings (listing creation), default acceptance (pricing), counter-offers (proposal management), and the pause feature (retention) all allow the host to modulate their exposure without fully confronting or fully retreating from it. This maps directly to Becker's insight that repression is not merely negative but 'lives on life energies and uses them creatively' — the pause function repurposes the host's anxiety into a productive holding pattern rather than destructive flight.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: User stories: 'Pause matters more than delete.' Journey map: counter-offer mechanism allows partial retreat. Becker Ch. 2: 'Repression is not simply a negative force opposing life energies; it lives on life energies and uses them creatively.'

cross_phase_patterns.description: The guest — as an abstract concept in early phases and as a specific person in later phases — functions throughout the journey as what Becker calls a 'complex symbol of death.' In discovery, the stranger is hypothetical and therefore manageable. In listing creation, the stranger becomes implied (someone will see these photos). In proposal management, the stranger becomes named and specific. In active lease, the stranger is physically present. This increasing concreteness of the stranger tracks with increasing demands on the host's character armor. The platform's entire UX challenge is to mediate this progression so that the stranger becomes manageable rather than terrifying at each stage.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Becker Ch. 2: 'The child's concept of death is not a single thing, but rather a composite of mutually contradictory paradoxes — death itself is not only a state, but a complex symbol.' User stories: 'Messaging is the highest cross-activation story... it's the moment two strangers begin to trust each other through the platform.'

cross_phase_patterns.description: The platform provides a series of micro-rituals (wizard steps, confirmation dialogs, cleaning photos, arrival notifications, stay reviews) that function as what Becker describes as 'the ways of the world that the child learns and in which he lives later as a kind of grim equanimity.' These rituals maintain the host's sense of control and predictability, allowing repression of the underlying terror to continue functioning. When any ritual is skipped or broken (guest doesn't send cleaning photos, review is negative, notification is missed), the repression temporarily fails and raw anxiety surfaces.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Becker Ch. 2: 'All he has to do is to plunge ahead in a compulsive style of drivenness in the ways of the world.' Journey map: confirmation dialogs at every critical action, cleaning photo protocol, arrival notifications, stay reviews. User stories: 'Urgency should surface first on the dashboard.'
